Section.title: What You Need To Know First
Section.Paragraph: In order to start using the application, you'll need to know a few details first:

ListUnordered.Item:
You'll need to know the configuration details of one or more S3 buckets that you'll be using to receive data. Configuring an S3 bucket on a server is outside the scope of this documentation and is, in any case, very provider-specific. Assuming that you have created an S3 bucket on a server, you'll need to know the following:
The bucket name.
The bucket access key.
The bucket secret key.
The bucket region.
The bucket endpoint.
If you want to use QR code configuration, you'll need to know how to use QR encoding tools. The qrtool package comes highly recommended.

Subsection.title: Overview
Subsection.Paragraph: The application opens to a set of tabs. The initially visible tab is the Buckets tab. This is, unsurprisingly, where you'll configure the S3 buckets to which you want to upload files. The buttons in the toolbar allow for configuring an S3 bucket manually or, alternatively, configuring an S3 bucket from a QR code.

Subsection.title: Manual Configuration
Subsection.Paragraph: Clicking the Create Bucket toolbar button opens a screen that allows for configuring the details of an S3 bucket manually.

The Reference Name field holds the name that you'll use to refer to the bucket in other parts of the application. This name can be anything, although there are some restrictions on the characters that are allowed to be used in the name. Don't worry; the UI will tell you if a name is valid or not as you type each character. The name can't be changed later, so try to pick something useful and descriptive.

The Name field holds the actual name of the S3 bucket as it appears on the server. Amazon S3 in particular has
a long list of restrictions on the names of buckets.
The Region field holds the region within this bucket resides. For self-hosted options such as MinIO, the region will always be us-east-1.

The Access Key field holds the access key that will be used to access the bucket. You can think of an access key as being analogous to a username in other systems. Typically, this will either be a username, or it'll be an IAM role and will look like a short string of random alphanumeric characters.
The Secret Key field holds the secret key that will be used to access the bucket. You can think of a secret key as being analogous to a password in other systems.

The Access Style menu declares the method by which the bucket will be accessed. This option is slightly esoteric, and the value you select will depend on which S3 storage provider you're using on the server side. On Amazon AWS, at the time of writing, Amazon are recommending that people use
virtual host
style access. In virtual host mode, you would specify the endpoint of the server as, for example, https://s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com. Then, for a bucket named example-23, the S3 client would actually make requests to the address https://example-23.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com behind the scenes.

In contrast, for path style access, the name of the bucket is simply added at the end of the endpoint URL. In path style mode, you would specify the endpoint of the server as, for example, https://s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com. Then, for a bucket named example-23, the S3 client would actually make requests to the address https://s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com/example-23 behind the scenes.
Systems such as MinIO require the use of path style access. Amazon AWS currently accepts either access style in practice. Consult your S3 provider's documentation for the rules.

Finally, the Endpoint field specifies the actual base address that will be used for the S3 bucket. If you're hosting S3 buckets yourself using MinIO, then this is simply the address of the server. If you're hosting S3 buckets on AWS, then this will be an address such as https://s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com. Again, you'll need to consult your S3 provider's documentation for the right server endpoint to use.

Once you've configured all the fields, and none of the fields are showing a red warning icon, you can click the Save Bucket button in the toolbar to save the bucket. Don't worry if you realize you got some of the details wrong; you can modify buckets at any time. Once you have at least one bucket defined, you can proceed to the uploads tab.

Subsection.title: QR Code Configuration
Subsection.Paragraph: Entering long strings of characters using on-screen keyboards can be painful. To alleviate some of that pain, it's possible to use third-party tools to put configuration information into a QR code, and then have the application scan the QR code to automatically configure a bucket.

Data in the QR code must be in the
Java properties
format. This is a simple line-based format where each line specifies a key and a value, separated by either a colon or an equals symbol. Key names are case-sensitive.
For example, a valid configuration in this format might look like this:

FormalItem.title: Example Configuration
FormalItem.Verbatim: AccessKey=fc87a046 AccessStyle=PATH_STYLE Bucket=tablet-test Endpoint=https://s3.example.com Name=qrtest Region=us-west-1 SecretKey=03cbe0c80539c8bb2883c2f3bb239f62cab89493

Subsection.Paragraph: When given to a QR encoding tool, the following image will be produced:
This table lists the keys and their meanings:

Row.Cell: The bucket access style. Must be PATH_STYLE or VIRTUALHOST_STYLE.
The name of the bucket on the server.

Subsection.Paragraph: Upon clicking the Create Bucket (from QR code) toolbar button, the device's camera will open and you will be given an opportunity to scan a QR code. Assuming the QR code is correctly scanned, the bucket configuration screen will open, and you'll be given a chance to review and/or modify the parsed configuration values.

In practical terms, none of the keys listed above are required to be present in the QR code. If a key is missing, you will simply have to enter the corresponding value manually on the bucket configuration screen after scanning.
Once you have at least one bucket defined, you can proceed to the uploads tab.

Subsection.title: Modify Buckets
Subsection.Paragraph: Clicking a bucket in the bucket list will take you back to the manual configuration screen and allow you to change the details for a bucket.

Subsection.title: Delete Buckets
Subsection.Paragraph: Clicking the checkbox on the right hand side of a bucket selects that bucket for deletion. With one or more buckets selected, a Delete Bucket button becomes accessible in the toolbar. Clicking the Delete Bucket button asks for confirmation and then deletes the selected buckets. Note that, if a bucket is deleted, any uploads associated with the bucket will also be deleted.

Subsection.title: Overview
Subsection.Paragraph: The Uploads tab is where you'll tell the application about the data you want to upload. If the Buckets tab is considered to describe where the data will end up, then the Uploads tab can be considered to describe what data is uploaded to any given bucket, and when exactly those uploads occur.

Subsection.title: Configuration
Subsection.Paragraph: The Create Upload button in the toolbar opens a configuration screen to allow for defining new uploads.

In a similar manner to bucket reference names, the Upload Name field holds the name you'll use to refer to the upload in other parts of the application. This name can be anything, although there are some restrictions on the characters that are allowed to be used in the name. Don't worry; the UI will tell you if a name is valid or not as you type each character. The name can't be changed later, so try to pick something useful and descriptive.

The Device Directory field holds the name of the directory that will be scanned for files for this upload. Unfortunately, Android has been steadily moving towards restricting access to the device filesystem for years. It's therefore likely to be much easier to use the Select Directory button to choose a directory on the device than to try to manually enter a path that Android will actually accept. The implementation section of this manual has details on the generally user-hostile configuration that Android now provides.
The Schedule menu allows for selecting how frequently an upload will be attempted, assuming that no other events trigger it into running. The menu allows for one of the following values:

Row.Cell: The upload will be attempted every five minutes.
The upload will be attempted every ten minutes.
The upload will be attempted every twenty minutes.
The upload will be attempted every thirty minutes.
The upload will be attempted every sixty minutes.
No schedule; only upload on trigger events.
The upload will not use a time-based schedule and will only start in response to one or more of the configured trigger events having occurred.
The upload will not use a time-based schedule and will only start if you manually trigger it.

Subsection.Paragraph: The Bucket menu allows for selecting a bucket to which to upload. The values in the menu correspond to the reference names of any buckets you have configured.
The various switches in the Triggers section specify events that will cause the upload to start running. The currently supported trigger events include:

Row.Cell: The upload will start when a photo is taken. This can be useful for ensuring that photos taken on the device camera are promptly sent to the server.

The upload will start when the network moves from a state that is considered "unavailable" to a state that is considered "available". The precise meaning of this is described in the implementation section of this manual.

Subsection.Paragraph: Once you've configured all the fields, and none of the fields are showing a red warning icon, you can click the Save Upload button in the toolbar to save the upload. Don't worry if you realize you got some of the details wrong; you can modify uploads at any time. Once you have at least one upload defined, you can proceed to the status tab.

Subsection.title: Modify Uploads
Subsection.Paragraph: In a similar manner to bucket modification, clicking an upload in the upload list will take you back to the configuration screen and allow you to change the details for an upload.

Subsection.title: Delete Uploads
Subsection.Paragraph: In a similar manner to bucket deletion, clicking the checkbox on the right hand side of an upload selects that upload for deletion. With one or more uploads selected, a Delete Upload button becomes accessible in the toolbar. Clicking the Delete Upload button asks for confirmation and then deletes the selected uploads.

Subsection.title: Overview
Subsection.Paragraph: The Status tab shows the current status of every defined upload. The Start/Stop Upload button allows for manually starting uploads, or cancelling uploads that are currently running. Clicking on an item in the status list will open a details screen for the most recent execution of an upload.

Subsection.title: Details
Subsection.Paragraph: The details screen for a given upload shows information about the most recent execution of an upload.
The details page displays the following fields:

Row.Cell: The unique execution ID of the upload. Each execution of an upload will be assigned a new ID.
The reference name of the bucket to which data is being uploaded.
The time and date the upload started.
The time and date the upload ended (assuming that it has ended).
The total duration of the upload (assuming that it has ended).
The number of files that were discovered by the most recent scan of the directory associated with the upload.
The number of files that were skipped because it was determined that they had already been fully uploaded by a previous upload attempt, and their contents had not changed since then.
The number of files that failed to be uploaded due to some kind of error.

The number of files that were successfully uploaded during this upload execution. It is normal for this value to be zero if no files have been created or changed since the last execution of this upload.

Subsection.title: Overview
Subsection.Paragraph: The Settings tab shows the global settings for the application.

Subsection.title: Networking
Subsection.Paragraph: The Networking section of the settings screen controls how the application will handle the general aspects of networking on mobile devices.

The Allow uploads on cellular connections option, if enabled, will allow uploads to occur if the device's networking is being provided by some kind of cellular connection. This option is disabled by default, as the use of these kinds of networks can be financially costly for some users.
The Allow uploads on Wi-Fi option, if enabled, will allow uploads to occur if the device's networking is being provided by Wi-Fi. This option is enabled by default.

Subsection.title: Upload
Subsection.Paragraph: The Upload section of the settings screen provides general settings that affect all uploads.
The Pause uploads option, if enabled, will prevent all uploads from executing until the control is disabled. Note that uploads that are currently in progress will not be cancelled.

Subsection.title: User Manual
Subsection.Paragraph: The User Manual option will open the user manual in a web browser.

Subsection.title: Support
Subsection.Paragraph: The Support option will open a web browser and take you to a location where you may be able to get technical support for the application.

Subsection.title: Privacy Policy
Subsection.Paragraph: The Support option will open the application's privacy policy in a web browser.

Subsection.title: Commit
Subsection.Paragraph: The Commit option shows the unique identifier of the source code commit that was used to build the application.

Subsection.title: Version
Subsection.Paragraph: The Version option shows the current application version number.
